content: why lock here welcome back painting I'm a terrible
painter everything I know I learned from YouTube the paint scheme is nothing
special but in the interest of consistency and completion we'll walk
through it together here we go the first step is pretty easy
black vomit the only tips I have here which you probably already know are in
order to get the black paint into the nooks and crannies of the bricks be sure
you wet the brush with some water and don't attempt to abuse black spray paint
or else you'll melt the foam bricks the next step is to sponge stamp a neutral
medium gray this is DM Scotty's technique and he uses it all the time
you'll do the tiles in all of the squares sponge heavier or lighter
depending on the style you're going for I prefer about 50% coverage such that a
good amount of black still shows through keep in mind there's about to be another
round of sponging after this one one tip from my experimenting go lightly on the
bricks you do not want them to be solid gray with black cracks rather but 50% of
the brick surface should remain black just like the rest of the tile I found
that this helps add further depth of detail keep it light
next up is another round of sponging with a lighter gray I recommend that
however aggressive you were with the dark gray you aim to do half that much
with the light gray additionally do not apply the light gray to the bricks we
want the floor to pop out not the walls trust me you want them to look slightly
different you
now get out a rich brown color burnt umber is not bold enough what I use is
called bark brown pick out a few random bricks on each tile and cover them don't
dry brush or try for partial coverage make the entire brick surface brown two
to three bricks per wall is appropriate finally it's time to assemble warm up
the hot glue gun first attach squares that you know don't
need to be cut in other words any square knot adjacent to a wall then chop off a
quarter inch in order to fit the wall adjacent tiles in their places when you
do that ensure that the straight chopped side is against the wall
there's one more video after this one on how to handle doors but that's for tile
construction proper the job is done even if you don't switch to the
one-and-a-quarter grid system I hope you at least got some ideas for construction
techniques to apply to your own tiles so again there's one more after this but
this whole thing was a beginning not an end so I have a lot of cool stuff
planned and I hope to have you as a YouTube follower so till next time
